headline.main: The Farm Bill, Beyond the Farm

docs.abstract: In this sprawling legislation, what is missing that should be added? What is in the bill but should be eliminated?

docs.abstract: Virginia's ultrasound bill should have the right-wing howling about government coercion.

headline.main: When Gay Employees Can Enroll Spouses for Health Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: Some financially strong Catholic-sponsored medical centers are joining with smaller secular hospitals, in some cases limiting access to treatments like contraception and abortion.

headline.seo: Growth of Catholic Hospitals May Limit Access to Reproductive Care
headline.main: Catholic Hospitals Expand, Religious Strings Attached
headline.print_headline: Catholic Gains In Health Care Include Strings

docs.abstract: Some financially strong Catholic-sponsored medical centers are increasingly joining with small secular hospitals, in some cases limiting access to treatments like contraception, abortion and sterilization; this trend in health care economics is magnifying the tension as Roman Catholic leaders and government officials clash over the proper role of religion and reproductive health.
docs.snippet: Some financially strong Catholic-sponsored medical centers are joining with smaller secular hospitals, in some cases limiting access to treatments like contraception and abortion.

headline.main: Santorum Steps Up Critique of Obama's Worldview

headline.main: Intergenerational Accounting at the Public Mutual Fund and Insurance Company

docs.abstract: Assessing tax paid and benefits derived across the span of people's lives provides a more accurate picture than here-and-there snapshots, an economist writes.

headline.main: Rick Santorum and the Politics of Theology

docs.abstract: In Mr. Santorum’s eyes, unless you adopt his particularly Christian theology, you can’t be his kind of president.

docs.lead_paragraph: The owner of a prospering cleaning business in the Bronx and others in competitive, low-skill businesses worry that customers will be lost.

headline.seo: Fearing a Minimum Wage Increase Will Be Bad for Business
headline.main: Fearing a Minimum Wage Increase Will Be Bad for Business
headline.print_headline: Fearing That a Pay Raise Will Be Bad for Business

docs.abstract: Charles Cestaro, who runs a cleaning business in the Bronx, pays most of his workers $7.25 an hour, the federal minimum wage; New York State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg have proposed raising the state minimum wage to $8.50 an hour, but Cestaro fears that if he raises wages and charges more he will lose customers, a concern shared by other business owners in low-skilled industries.
docs.snippet: The owner of a prospering cleaning business in the Bronx and others in competitive, low-skill businesses worry that customers will be lost.

docs.lead_paragraph: After accusing President Obama of “a phony theology” and likening public schools to “factories” on Saturday, Rick Santorum sought to clarify his remarks but did not back down from them.

headline.seo: Santorum Defends Remarks on Obama and Public Schools
headline.main: Santorum Defends Remarks on Obama and Government’s Role in Education
headline.print_headline: Santorum Defends Remarks on Obama and Government’s Role in Education

docs.abstract: Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum seems to be displaying a newfound swagger and letting loose with free-swinging remarks, but a number of his statements are drawing criticism, illustrating one of the perils of political success--the same acclaim that brings confidence also brings greatly increased scrutiny.
docs.snippet: After accusing President Obama of “a phony theology” and likening public schools to “factories” on Saturday, Rick Santorum sought to clarify his remarks but did not back down from them.
